Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Plasma-Soft Matter interactions: Towards understanding the effect of nonequilibrium, cold plasma on liquid phase chemical reactions in cells using novel chemical sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1249787
Foster
Plasma medicine is a new and emerging subfield of healthcare in which ionized gas (plasma) is used for the purpose of therapy and the treatment of disease. Because the ionized gas or plasma is produced at normal atmospheric pressure and room temperature, it can readily be applied to injured or diseased human tissue. The scope of plasma medicine includes 1) sterilization of medical instruments or human tissue?directly addressing ?super bugs? such as flesh eating bacteria 2) wound healing 3) dental care?from tooth cleaning to root canals 4) topical skin treatment 5) anti-fungal therapies 6) treatment of chronic disease such as Crohn?s syndrome 7) management of blood coagulation 8) cosmetic surgery, and even 9) the treatment of cancer. It is clear that plasma medicine holds great potential and new vistas for the field of medicine in general. While the transformational potential of plasmas for therapy and sterilization in the medical field is well documented, a systematic investigation into the effects of plasma irradiation on living tissue has yet to be carried out. Missing is a systematic study that truly elucidates the healing mechanisms. Further it can be argued that lacking are adequate tools necessary to observe and measure the plasma-induced changes within cells (soft matter) directly. This research aims to differentiate between the cause and the effect of plasma exposure on cell chemistry by identifying the plasma species that are incident on and returning from biological tissues treated by plasmas, and characterizing the plasma-driven reactions within the cell itself. It is this plasma-soft matter interaction that is of paramount importance. In this investigation, free-standing, chemistry-sensitive nano-probes injected into the cells under study will be used to investigate and quantify intracellular chemical changes brought on by plasma exposure. Changes in fluorescence signal from the injected nano-probes dispersed within the cell reflect specific changes in internal cell conditions such as pH level, oxygen, or radical concentration. The ionized gas source to be used in this research is a ?cold? plasma jet. The jet is highly collimated and highly directional, making application to the cell substrate relatively straightforward. Internal cell changes will be correlated with plasma conditions, which in turn will be characterized using microwave and optical diagnostics. The proposed methodology is novel and groundbreaking in that it paves the way for real time analysis of the effect of plasma on cell chemistry thereby leading to an understanding of the curative properties of plasmas. This research effort is high payoff in that it has the potential to lay the foundation for a direct assessment of plasma-induced conditions within the cell as a function of plasma exposure time, thereby truly quantifying and ultimately understanding the effect of plasma exposure on the cell.

The broader impact of the proposed work is broad in that it investigates a novel approach to assessing effects induced at the intercellular level when living cells are exposed to plasma. The data obtained in this study is expected to provide a basis for understanding the therapeutic effects associated with plasma medicine. The understanding gained from this effort will also be useful in tailoring plasma therapy equipment as the relationship between the plasma generator settings and effects induced at the cellular level will be well quantified. To date, plasma medicine development has been somewhat ?Edisonian? in approach. While in any new and emerging field, this approach can be effective early on, to obtain an understanding of mechanisms involved from a human therapy standpoint, diagnostics are needed to guide the development and provide the foundations for predictive theory. The effort is expected to contribute to the growth and potential mainstreaming of the exciting new field of plasma medicine by providing a direct, near real-time diagnostics for measuring plasma-induced effects within the cell itself. This work contributes to the field of healthcare as it has been demonstrated that plasma medicine among other things clearly enhances wound healing. Outpatient wound treatment is a many-billion dollar field worldwide (20 billion dollars annually in the U.S. alone) addressing those who suffer from chronic wounds (diabetics for example)?nearly 6 million in the US alone.

POR.DRECONTENT: Plasma medicine is an emerging subfield of healthcare that features the use of plasma (ionized gas) for curative, therapeutic, or sterilization applications. Plasma treatments have demonstrated the capacity to heal wounds more rapidly than traditional methods.  This potential application could greatly benefit those with chronic wounds (~6.5 million patients, >$25 billion spent on treatment annually in U.S.).  Plasma treatments can also destroy drug resistant bacteria such as MRSA.  Indeed the field of plasma medicine stands poised to revolutionize the medical field.  Standing between widespread use of this approach and actual practice is a thorough understanding of the effect that plasma has on living tissue.  The objective of this research was to study the effect of plasma exposure on the internal chemistry of the cell itself.  Plasmas featured in plasma medicine applications are generated in regular, room temperature air. Plasma interaction with the air and its feed gas produces a host of radical species such as ozone, atomic oxygen, OH, NOx, UV, electrons and ions.  These species have the capacity to driven chemical reactions in the cell medium as well as within the cell itself.  The mechanism by which these plasma-produced species generate the curative effect is not understood.  In this work we utilize nanoparticle sensors that are inserted in the cell itself for the purpose of measuring chemical changes within.  These nanosenors are small and nontoxic to the cell. They can be functionalized to measure ion and radical concentrations. Changes in the chemical environment affect their fluorescence properties.  When the cells containing nanoparticle sensors are illuminated with laser light, the fluorescence signature changes in response to changes in the local chemical environment. In this effort, we measured plasma-induced changes in cell internal pH as well as reactive oxygen species.  It was found that the cells pH did not change appreciably with cell exposure, suggesting cell robustness.  On the other hand, we did find that the plasma exposure did greatly increase the concentration of reactive oxygen species within the cell. Presumably the reactive oxygen species passed through the cell membrane either directly from the gas phase or via modification of cell media, followed by diffusion into the cell through the cell membrane.  We also were able to quantify the effect of continuous and cumulative plasma exposure on cell viability.  It turns out that total treatment time is not the determining factor in regards to the upper limit for plasma exposure. Rather, it was found that provided the treatment time interval was not too long, the cells could always recover.  This is to say whereas a long continuous treatment time could lead to cell death, the same total treatment time given over intervals with some finite recovery time did not result in cell death.  Plasma induced cell morphology effects were also quantified in this study.  In summary, for the first time, internal chemical changes within the cell itself brought on by plasma exposure were quantified using nanoparticle sensors and dyes.  We were able to understand the affect that plasma treatment had on both pH and reactive oxygen species within the cell. POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Plasma medicine is an emerging subfield of healthcare that features the use of plasma (ionized gas) for curative, therapeutic, or sterilization applications. Plasma treatments have demonstrated the capacity to heal wounds more rapidly than traditional methods. This potential application could greatly benefit those with chronic wounds (~6.5 million patients, >$25 billion spent on treatment annually in U.S.). Plasma treatments can also destroy drug resistant bacteria such as MRSA. Indeed the field of plasma medicine stands poised to revolutionize the medical field. Standing between widespread use of this approach and actual practice is a thorough understanding of the effect that plasma has on living tissue. The objective of this research was to study the effect of plasma exposure on the internal chemistry of the cell itself. Plasmas featured in plasma medicine applications are generated in regular, room temperature air. Plasma interaction with the air and its feed gas produces a host of radical species such as ozone, atomic oxygen, OH, NOx, UV, electrons and ions. These species have the capacity to driven chemical reactions in the cell medium as well as within the cell itself. The mechanism by which these plasma-produced species generate the curative effect is not understood. In this work we utilize nanoparticle sensors that are inserted in the cell itself for the purpose of measuring chemical changes within. These nanosenors are small and nontoxic to the cell. They can be functionalized to measure ion and radical concentrations. Changes in the chemical environment affect their fluorescence properties. When the cells containing nanoparticle sensors are illuminated with laser light, the fluorescence signature changes in response to changes in the local chemical environment. In this effort, we measured plasma-induced changes in cell internal pH as well as reactive oxygen species. It was found that the cells pH did not change appreciably with cell exposure, suggesting cell robustness. On the other hand, we did find that the plasma exposure did greatly increase the concentration of reactive oxygen species within the cell. Presumably the reactive oxygen species passed through the cell membrane either directly from the gas phase or via modification of cell media, followed by diffusion into the cell through the cell membrane. We also were able to quantify the effect of continuous and cumulative plasma exposure on cell viability. It turns out that total treatment time is not the determining factor in regards to the upper limit for plasma exposure. Rather, it was found that provided the treatment time interval was not too long, the cells could always recover. This is to say whereas a long continuous treatment time could lead to cell death, the same total treatment time given over intervals with some finite recovery time did not result in cell death. Plasma induced cell morphology effects were also quantified in this study. In summary, for the first time, internal chemical changes within the cell itself brought on by plasma exposure were quantified using nanoparticle sensors and dyes. We were able to understand the affect that plasma treatment had on both pH and reactive oxygen species within the cell. This study represents a first step to obtaining a fundamental understanding of mechanisms by which plasma treatment leads to curative effects. This work lays down the diagnostic groundwork for a comprehensive study of the range of chemical processes taking place within the cell in response to plasma exposure. This understanding provides the basis for the development of a fundamental model relating plasma treatment to cell or tissue response. Such an understanding is critical for the development of curative therapies, which rely on plasma dosage.
